segments.text: Dan sat in his usual spot at the cafe by the window facing the street and gazed at the large tree growing near the entrance.
In the humid tropical air, everything grew to enormous sizes, even without anyone watering it.
Green shrubs outlined the cafe's yard, with red flower cups peeking out from some of them.
Sometimes, when he looked at the green yard with the big tree, he remembered the beautiful and well-kept garden of the pink house, and immediately felt a pang of longing.

He couldn't afford such emotions, which would distract him from everything passing by, but it was uncontrollable, and he didn't understand how he had endured so far, how he hadn't broken, got up, and returned without finishing his task.
The cafe owner had become his friend over the long months.
He hadn't guessed who this man was and was sure he was older than his real age as he put so much effort into his disguised appearance.
He also adopted a slightly hunched walk and usually wore a beret that almost covered his eyes.
The Spanish he spoke had a local slang from the year he studied there as a child, a time when his father was sent to that country by the foreign ministry.
This place seemed frozen in time.
It remained as it was in the 1950s
Outdated vehicles, buses with long noses slowly made their way down narrow streets on patchy asphalt, marked to cover potholes created by heavy tropical rain.
The people remained warm, friendly and cheerful, living simply, almost in poverty.
But they didn't feel it because everyone lived that way and because almost everything they needed grew on the trees around them.
If that wasn't enough, at the city's outskirts, chickens roamed freely, laying eggs and serving as meat.
Locals found reasons to celebrate everything, playing their wonderful music loudly, so even the neighbors could hear.
The windows were wide open, and it wasn't unusual to hear someone singing along with the radio, slowly joined by other listeners nearby.
Everyone dressed simply, and due to the intense heat, little fabric was needed.
Yet they had style.
Men were always found wearing button shirts even over shorts and moccasins that they polished and shined.
And some kind of hat, some are white fedoras, looking like they were taken from the Italian mafia.
berets in various colors.
The main thing was to have something on the head to wave in greeting when passing a friend.
The women wore sleeveless floral dresses made from light fabrics and always walked in heels.

Most sewed their dresses themselves, and their high heels were repeatedly repaired by the cobbler until they finally gave out, perhaps due to the place's remoteness from western countries, perhaps because it remained somewhat backward.
not allowing progress to change it.
It became a haven for some of the worst Nazi criminals.
Some had already passed away by one means or another, leaving only three living there, each in different parts of the island under assumed names and without a soul knowing of their existence.
It's possible that before arriving there, they had no idea that this island was one of the few that allowed Jewish refugees fleeing the horrors of the Holocaust to settle without conditions.
Coffee, Sr.
Pedro?"
asked Julio from the café.
This warm and simple man had become his close friend during his stay, without any idea of who he was or what he was looking for there.
See, he replied, Gracias.
What's interesting in the newspaper today?
Julio asked.
This had become their daily conversation.
He explained everything significant.
who died, who was born, and how much the price of rice rose.
From where he sat, he could observe a large part of the street and some of the house entrances, watching precisely who entered, who left, and what they carried.
He pretended to be lost in thought, as if he had no interest in the passersby, but nothing escaped his notice.
Of course, one entrance in particular caught his interest.
In the afternoons, he would return home for the traditional siesta.
Not a soul would be on the street.
Julio would also close the café.
Only after three hours would he return to the street, this time to the restaurant at the other end, ordering Aroscon Boyo, rice with chicken, from Isabella, Manuel's wife, who greeted him warmly.
From her stories, he knew that Manuel's grandfather fled Poland to the island toward the end of World War II.
His father and he were born on the island.
Manuel was Jewish and she was Christian.
But on the restaurant's windowsill stood a large menorah and a large chain with a cross hung at the entrance.
God is everyone's, Isabella would say.
Locals always saw the handful of Jews as chosen people, intelligent and successful.
In his heart, he often thought it was good to know this.
If he ever needed help, he might find an ally in Manuel.
One time when he fell ill with dengue fever and suffered from high fever, Julio came to visit him at his apartment after he hadn't shown up at the cafe for two days, worried about his well-being.
It was the first time someone entered his apartment, his fortress.
The apartment was furnished simply, almost spartan.
There were very few possessions, a radio, an armchair, and an old sofa.
Julio saw his condition and called Dr. Adelstein.
There was no need to be a big expert to know he was one of ours, but he worried the doctor might see him at his lowest and immediately understand he was Jewish and might say something.
His condition didn't allow him to think clearly, yet something in the back of his mind set off all his alarm bells.
Dr. Edelstein took his temperature, listened to his breathing, and to his great relief was satisfied with that.
I'll give you an injection and pills.
It should pass in two days, the doctor said.
If not, we'll have to hospitalize you.
Then the doctor turned to Julio and asked him to provide food and plenty of tea and water for him.
He must drink a lot and flush the fever out of his system.
Once the doctor and Julio left his home, he breathed a sigh of relief, understanding that for now the danger had passed.
In those two days of high fever, he was delirious and returned to her in his dreams.

seeing himself washing her to lower her fever, sinking momentarily into her deep blue gaze, sailing to her in his mind, embraced in his arms, burying his head in the nape of her neck, almost able to smell her hair.
What wouldn't he give to have her here by his side?
That week he experienced moments of breaking.

Despite his mental strength and understanding the magnitude of the mission he was committed to, perhaps because his body was weak, his spirit also waned, and he just wanted to return home to her arms.
Even so, she tormented his dreams at night, often seeing her in her garden, raking, watering, bending over her wicker baskets, and suddenly lifting her eyes to him with a big, warm smile.
Sometimes it seemed a baby was crawling beside her on the large lawn.
What was he doing there?
Upon waking from such mornings, he wondered if she had found someone else in his place, was already married, and a mother.
But immediately, he dismissed the thought from his mind.
It couldn't be.
He knew she loved him.
He felt it in every fiber of his being, even from the deep look she casted him when she lifted her head to him in his dream.
She trusted him.
He could almost hear her saying it.
A year and a half are endless, but he knew the day wasn't far when he would complete his mission.
Just a bit longer, he whispered to her in his heart, wait a bit longer.
In those weeks, a spirit of melancholy fell over her day and night.
She began to think that perhaps she had been too naive to believe Dan would return, and if he did, that he would return to her.
At night, she dreamt he had found himself a plump, pretty local girl to spend his days with.
On such mornings, she'd wake with a pinch in her heart, even then trying to rationalize that it was long for him too, and how long could he wait?
Suddenly, she'd jump.
And how long can I wait?
Along with all of this, it was also a rather dry period at her small hotel.
Only a few tenants visited, and she had almost no income from it.
With all the maintenance and food costs, very little was left.
Occasionally, she was also gripped by the fear that the interim Yehuda allocated for her was running out, and although the time wasn't precisely defined, if.
Yehuda just decided it could end abruptly, time and again she thought maybe she should stop waiting for Dan so innocently and confidently.
Perhaps it was better to continue her life and focus on what she could do if truly left alone as a single parent.
She would look at him as he slept beside her and feel a pain in her heart.
How much he resembled Dan.
Every time her gaze rested on him, a deep longing that she felt in her whole body spread within her.
These emotional swings were new to her.
One moment she was confident in his love and the next moment doubts arose within her.
And when all this was accompanied by financial lack, she was sucked into a gloomy mood she found difficult to shake off.
The day before, Albert from the grocery store looked at her.
You're not like always, he noted.
What happened?
Is everything OK?
Where's your bright smile?
Can I help with anything?
She looked at him and fought to herself that this warm and simple man knew how to read her soul and genuinely cared for her.
If it's the money, he added, just write it down for now.
I know that when you have it, you'll run to pay me."
That would really help, she said.
But it's not just that.
I'm a bit tired of waiting, of being alone.
It's so long and the longing takes over.
This will pass.
It's temporary and will fade.
Albert looked at her gently.
You'll see.
It will sort out.
Sometimes in life there's no choice and patience is needed.
Things get drawn out without us wanting, but somehow, in the end, they do settle.
Good Albert, how comforting it was for her to hear him console her.
Maybe she just didn't speak enough with people.
Too many hours she spent alone, just with her son, and as much joy as he brought her, he couldn't replace conversations with adults.
As she and Ben walked back home from Albert's grocery, she found herself speaking to him aloud as if trying to convince herself.
Dad is coming back soon.
He's gone far away and he'll come by airplane when he finishes his work, get off the airplane and come straight to us and give us a big, big hug.
Ben looked at her, not really understanding what she wanted, but when she finished her words, he smiled and clapped, happy.
Dad, dad, he said as if reciting, knowing his dad from stories.
Surprisingly, she felt somewhat calmed.
A bit of Albert, a bit of Ben, and she wrote it down at the grocery.
Maybe she'd even managed to sleep well without dreaming of a tanned girl comforting Dan in her arms and pinching her heart.
